field_edited_text.value:
The Pros and Cons of Expressways

i



center. The center thus enjoys a degree of superiority over A (or any
other similar outlying point) of better than 2 to 1. It is obvious that the
center’s margin of superiority over A is increased the farther one gets
from A. It would take 27 minutes to drive from the center to Point B;
54 minutes to drive from A to B.

Now let us change the circumstances somewhat. Let us assume that
an expressway in the form of a beltway is built around the city 8 miles
from the center. Let us also assume that one can travel on this beltway
at an average speed of 40 miles per hour. The area now more accessible
to A than to the center will increase, as shown in Fig. 2(b), to the point
where it equals 50% of the metropolitan area. A, instead of being less
than half as accessible as the center, is now just as accessible. Further-
more, even within the area in which it still is dominant the center’s
margin of superiority over A is markedly less. It still takes 27 minutes to
travel from the center to B, but the travel time from A to B has dropped
from 54 minutes to 37 minutes. The previous 27 minutes differential has
thus been reduced to 10, a drop of almost 2/3.

Next, let us assume that in addition to the beltway a radial express-
way (allowing an average speed of 40 miles per hour) is built from the
center of the City due north to the limits of the metropolitan area. This
example is illustrated in Fig. 2(c). While the center has improved its
position somewhat in relationship to points on the east and west sides of
the beltway, fundamentally the situation is still the same as shown in
Fig. 2(b).

Finally, let us assume that three additional radial expressways are
constructed running from the center to the edge of the metropolitan area:
one to the east, one to the south, and one to the west. This condition is
illustrated in Fig. 2(d). Under these circumstances the center again has a
better than two to one superiority over point A or any similarly situated







2(0)





METROPOLITAN









2(d)

FIG. 2
